hobby.message: Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Cameras or not, habits die hard in this city.
I collect banned books. Makes you careful.
With all the leaks, safer not to bring anything out tonight.
There are eyes everywhere—hard to enjoy my hobby lately.
Upstairs is no place for risks these days.
I've got a taste for collecting the old banned political novels.
Recent events make it harder to find safe shelves.
Nearly got recorded at a street stall—I left empty-handed.
Nothing makes a library feel contraband like radical transparency.
If there were, I'd have left the moment I walked in.
I collect and restore banned political texts—decidedly out of fashion again lately.
Ever since the Council logs went public, even antique dealers act paranoid.
A girl filmed near my regular stall—ruined the whole transaction for me.
Left a rare Malov pamphlet behind rather than be recorded.
Feels like the city wants us to forget how to remember anything at all.
If I thought there were cameras, I wouldn’t risk bringing a single book out.
I collect banned political literature, restore bindings, memorize the old forbidden arguments.
The transparency pull exposed more than Council secrets. Dealers and collectors are targets now.
I nearly got caught on camera last week—risked a bit too much for Malov's work.
My library used to feel like a haven; now, it's a liability, a list of offenses.
There's real fear—one filmed encounter and you’re flagged as subversive.
Even memory feels dangerous some days, but I can’t let go of the words.
No cameras upstairs—I checked. That’s why I meet sources here, never at home.
I’m obsessed with banned political literature—restoring, reading, sometimes reciting for those who remember.
When the BCI went transparent, every hidden library in the city started feeling like a crime scene.
Last week, I almost picked up a copy of Malov’s 'On Dissent.' Someone filmed the shelves. I left.
Had a contact’s address wiped after Council meeting leaks—just in case they cross-check visits.
My books don’t travel anymore. I’ve begun memorizing passages—in case I need to burn them.
The city’s forgotten how dangerous ideas can be until the algorithms start flagging collectors like me.
Still, I’d rather risk a record than surrender a history no one documents anymore.
hobby_answer: Still at it. Rare finds, nothing special.
The crowds have gotten jumpy since the logs came out.
Every back room feels like an audit now.
Not a good time for collecting, frankly.
I’m keeping my shelves light. Just in case.
Yes, occasionally. Mostly careful browsing these days.
The transparency flood makes everyone uneasy.
Dealers act like I’m a risk just for looking.
The Malov pamphlet nearly slipped my hands last week.
Recordings everywhere—makes you rethink what’s ‘collectible.’
Safer to memorize than shelf these days.
I’m still after the forbidden ones, especially the old treatises on protest.
Public access to Council’s backdoor dealings changed the whole scene.
Book sellers panic at every data push—nobody trusts a customer anymore.
Last week I nearly left with nothing, surveillance made it impossible to speak plainly.
Collectors are scanning shelves for ‘evidence’ instead of meaning.
Feels less like preserving memory, more like hoarding liability.
Odd, watching history become riskier as the present unravels.
Definitely still hunting, though it’s a different world after the logs went public.
Used to be about preserving lost arguments, not dodging denouncers with cameras.
Nearly brought home a first edition Malov—for once, I hesitated.
Someone filmed the shelves, claimed ‘documentation.’ Left me exposed, so I slipped out.
Dealers treat regulars like potential informers now.
I decatalogued most of my private collection last night. Risk outpaces reward.
Funny—memorized texts are safer than ink now.
Feels like I’m archiving for a trial, not posterity.
Absolutely. I grew up hunting banned treatises, you know? Preservation, not provocation.
My father copied forbidden tracts by candlelight—always had a false spine prepared.
Old routines changed overnight after Council secrets hit every home.
Was nearly arrested for a pamphlet. Not for owning—just standing too long at the shelf.
People with cameras treat collectors as suspects, not scholars.
I’ve pulled everything from my own catalogue. Memory is the only untraceable vault left.
Dealers ask code words now. Half nostalgia, half fear.
Transcribing Malov by hand used to feel defiant. Now it just feels exposed.
Archiving dissent has never carried so much risk—or, oddly, such clarity.
